intro: Lappa personata, commonly known as the common lappa, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other well-known plants such as cabbages and mustards. The plant typically grows to a height of about 1 to 2 meters, featuring erect stems covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are small, yellowish-green, and arranged in clusters, while its leaves are lance-shaped and have a slightly hairy texture. The plant is often found in meadows, along roadsides, and in disturbed soils.
